name: Beshbarmak
story: I missed beshbarmak most during Chuseok. Called my mom from Taraz, she was cooking it for the whole family. Tried to explain to Korean friends what 'five fingers' means.

name: Kurt
story: My grandma from Taraz used to make kurt for long journeys. In Korea, I found some stores and a neighborhood where they are sold, and I go there whenever I feel homesick.

name: Kimchi
story: My favorite side dish in Korean cuisine. I’d love to attend a kimchi-making master class. I buy it every time — it’s also very healthy.

name: Taraz Apples
story: Apples from Taraz are the sweetest. When I tried Korean apples, they were different - more crispy but less aromatic.

name: Tteokbokki
story: First korean street food I tried in my hometown, Taraz. My first experience with Korean cuisine, and I fell in love with it.

name: Baursak
story: I made them for a national dishes competition, and afterward, I shared them with my professors and Korean friends. They said it tasted like doughnuts, just without the sugar.

name: Plov
story: Actually, it’s a traditional Uzbek dish, but we cook and eat it so often in Kazakhstan that I couldn’t leave it off the list. Rice with meat, carrots, and garbanzo beans is simply heaven for me.

name: Kimbap
story: My go-to lunch at university, cheap and tasty

name: Samgyetang
story: Samgyetang is very good when you're sick. Immediately feel better and full of energy. Reminds me of how my mom in Taraz made chicken soup when I was ill.

name: Dakgalbi
story: Can't cook often because it's complicated to prepare, and going to restaurants is expensive because everywhere you need to order 2 portions, can't order just one.

name: Jajangmyeon
story: First Korean-Chinese food I tried. So different from lagman in Taraz!

name: Hotteok
story: Winter comfort food. Sweet and warm, perfect for cold Seoul days.
